entry.title: Re: How to handle ‚Äúusernames‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal User IDs‚Äù and ‚Äúexternal IDs‚Äù in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hello @1Gunnar @dyaryura @Colt 

First of all, thank you for the great support.

However, I‚Äôm still not completely clear on this.
What are the best practices for using the Global User ID and NameID (Subject Name Identifier) in IAS?

  • Is it best practice always  to use the Global User ID as the SNI (NameID) : NameID (SNI)  =Global User ID  ?
  • Or would it be better, for example, to set the NameID as the EmployeeNumber and send the Global User ID as an additional attribute: Name ID (SNI) = EmployeeNumber   and  additional Attribute = Global User ID ?

What are your recommendations or experiences on this?

Thank you very much  for your help.

Best Regards

entry.title: Data validation on extension version
entry.content:
Hi,

We have a standard version and an attached extension version. We use this extension version for currency rate simulations, meaning that in the extension version we only use slightly different currency rates but we do not change / enter any other data. The extension version does not allow LC, TC, QTY changes.

In our validation method we have a rule that checks whether the amount on an fs item across all document types is >= 0. We use this validation rule both for local currency data (task 1080) and group currency data (task 1180). We do this because we have manual posting, i.e. certain document types, in local currency but also in group currency.

We have now come across a case as follows.

The reported (flat file import) amount on a specific fs item in local currency is 100 in the standard version. The converted amount in group currency is 120. On the same fs item we also have a manual journal posted in group currency only of -118. 
=> in the standard version both the local currency and the group currency validation is fine as both amounts are greater than zero (100 in local and 2 in group currency).

In the extension version we have the same reported data and the same manual journal in group currency. However, due to the difference in exchange rate, the 100 local currency are converted to 117 in group currency.
=> in the extension version the validation in converted currency shows an error as the total of reported amount and manual journal is -1 and hence not equal to or greater than 0.

Ideally we would like to disable this validation for the extension version,  is that possible? Or how else could we deal with this situation in order to not receive an error in the data monitor for task 1180?

entry.title: Goods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to explain how to cancel the Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for External Procurement in Extended Warehouse Management, in addition to demonstrating the process steps for testing, we will also discuss about potential errors and current limitations.

This new Monitor Mehtod is available in both EWM deployments: Embedded and Decentralized.

Background Information:

With the new Method 'Reverse after Putaway' in Warehouse Management Monitor (i.e. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0), it is now finally possible to reverse a goods receipt for an inbound delivery/item in external procurement scenario (e.g. Purchase Order) in EWM, even if the Putaway Warehouse Task is already confirmed.

This gives the warehouse team more flexibility to trigger GR reversal at anytime when the error is observed maybe during picking, as long as the reference purchase documents are still exist in system (i.e. not Archived).

The new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) can be found in the following nodes in SAP Warehouse Management Monitor report (/SCWM/MON):
- Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock 
- Stock and Bin -> Storage Bin -> Physical Stock


Figure 01 - Simple Inbound Process Flow

Prerequisites:

  • Completion Status (DCO) for delivery item to be cancelled must be equal to 9-Completed
  • Purchase document is not archived
  • Quality inspection document is completed (if exists)
  • Authorization object /SCWM/SLFU with the value RS for Reverse Stock from External Procurement is assigned to your user.

Configuration Steps:

This configuration step is only required in Decentralized EWM deplopyment.

- Allow Reversal after Putaway for Completed LE Delivery
Navigate to SPRO -> Extended Warehouse Management-> Interfaces->ERP Integration->ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM-> Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control


Figure 02 - Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

Testing Steps:

NOTE: The following testing scenario has been executed on SAP S/4HANA OP2025 FPS00 with Embedded EWM.

Scenario: GR Reversal for Inbound Delivery with reference to a Purchase Order:
In this scenario we will post goods receipt for an inbound delivery created with reference to a purchase order, then we will trigger the goods receipt reversal for the received delivery item via the new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) in Warehouse Monitor report.

1- Create Purchase Order (Tx. ME21N / App. Create Purchase Order - Advanced)


Figure 03 - Create Purchase Order

2- Create Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution (Tx. VL31N / App. Create Inbound Delivery)


Figure 04 - Create Inbound Delivery in LE

3- Post Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries)


Figure 05 - Post GR in EWM


4- Create Putaway Warehouse Tasks  (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Create Warehouse Tasks - Inbound Delivery)


Figure 06 - Create Putaway WTs

Hint: don't forget to take a note of the destination storage bin number, to use it later on during the reversal step.

5- Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)


Figure 07 - Confirm Putaway WTs

6- Reverse Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)
 - Navigate to Warehouse Management Monitor report -> Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock.
- Select the stock line and click on More Methods -> Reverse after Putaway.


Figure 08/A - Select Reverse after Putaway method

 - Ensure to enter the exact quantity to be reversed. 
- You need to enter Inbound Delivery and Item numbers as well (if not proposed by system, in case of multiple reference documents exist).
- Then click Post GR Reversal button.


Figure 08/B - Post GR Reverseal in EWM

Hint: Material Document year/number/item could be entered as well if desired.

- If goods receipt reversal is successful, then a Warehouse Task of category 6-Goods Issue Posting will be created.


Figure 08/C - WT for GI is created

7- Check Inbound Delivery in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries) - Optional


Figure 09 - Check Inbound Delivery in EWM

In EWM inbound delivery, Goods Receipt and Putaway statutes will remain Completed (no changes).

8- Check Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution  (Tx. VL33N / App. Display Inbound Delivery) - Optional


Figure 10/A - Check Inbound Delivery GM Status in LE

In LE inbound delivery, the Goods Receipt status will remain Completed (no changes).


Figure 10/B - Check Inbound Delivery Document Flow in LE

But in the document flow, a goods reversal material document (w/ movement type 102) will be created and added.

9- Check Purchase Order History in ERP (Tx. ME23N  / App. Display Purchase Order)


Figure 11 - Check PO History in ERP

NOTE: In case the missing item has been delivered by supplier later on after the goods receipt reversal for the same item was executed, a new inbound delivery should be created in this case as re-posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was reversed is not possible.

 

Common Errors during Goods Receipt Reversal:

- M7328 - Deficit of Delivered quantity:
In case you enter higher quantity than original delivery item quantity.

- /SCWM/GM401 - Reversal for stock assigned to reference documents is not allowed:
In case you select a stock line with a delivery reference (i.e. DCO <> 9) or you select a stock item with open quality inspection document.

- /SCWM/GM402 - Stock Information in delivery/item - doesn't match selected stock:
In case you select a different stock line that doesn't match the inserted delivery information.

 

Out of Scope:

  • Posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was revesred.
  • Serial number managed materials. (only via API is possible)
  • Catch weight managed materials.
  • Purchase documents are archived.
  • STO, Merchandise Cross docking, and TCD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

It's now possible to reverse goods receipt after final putaway in EWM for external procurment scenario, using the new Monitor Method - Reversal after Putaway in Warehouse Management Report, the warehouse user is now able to trigger goods receipt reversal in EWM and ERP respectively without too much complexity or additional technical knowledge. 

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal.

For more information about reversal after putaway, please check Reversal of Goods Receipt from External Procurement | SAP Help Portal.

For more information about other new EWM features in S/4HANA 2025 FPS00, please check the following blog post by Gheorghe Ceres: SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New
 
Learn more about SAP Premium Engagement and how a global team of experts can help you to get the most out of your SAP solutions.

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement services can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!

#CoE EMEA SCM1

entry.title: October-November 2025 Live Sessions: Elevate Your SAP Customer Data Solutions
entry.content:
üåüLive Session: Elevate Customer Engagement with SAP Customer Data Cloud

üìÖDate: 10/27/2025

üìÑDescription
Are you ready to revolutionize customer identity and access management? Join us for an engaging live session on SAP Customer Data Cloud CIAM and discover how to elevate customer interactions to new heights. The session will explore how to build secure, scalable solutions with hands-on demos, and you will learn all about mastering the SAP CDC Console, CDC sites, and seamless login & registration flows. Don‚Äôt miss out‚Äîtransform your skills and your business with cutting-edge CIAM expertise!

üîóMore Info

üöÄLive Session: Unlocking the Potential of SAP Customer Data Cloud

üìÖDate: 10/29/2025

üìÑDescription
Ready to take control of your customer data like never before? Join our exhilarating live session on configuring the data schema of SAP Customer Data Cloud and discover how to optimize your customer data management. Dive into the intricacies of data stores, user account structures, schema fields, group models, and more. Get hands-on experience in configuring and designing a robust data store schema that meets all your organizational needs. Ignite your customer data management skills and unlock the full potential of SAP CDC!

üîóMore Info

üîßLive Session: Unlock Seamless Identity Management with SAP Customer Data Cloud REST API

üìÖDate: 10/30/2025

üìÑDescription
Are you ready to streamline your identity flows with cutting-edge API technology? Join our live session on using SAP Customer Data Cloud REST APIs to revolutionize identity management. Explore the powerful REST APIs, master essential tools and methods, and learn to implement these APIs to deliver seamless identity flows. Enhance your technical prowess and transform the way you handle customer identities!

üîóMore Info

üéìLive Session: Master the SAP Customer Data Platform by Implementing an End-to-End B2C Scenario

üìÖDate: 11/3/2025

üìÑDescription
Discover the power of SAP Customer Data Platform in our interactive B2C scenario live session! Dive deep into the world of customer data as you learn to implement comprehensive B2C scenarios. In this engaging live session, you'll master the art of ingesting customer profile and activity data, aggregating information from diverse sources, enforcing data privacy regulations, and generating actionable insights. Unlock new potential for your business by activating these insights across various destination systems. Join us and elevate your customer engagement strategy to new heights!

üîóMore Info

üè¢Live Session: B2B for SAP Customer Data Platform

üìÖDate: 11/4/2025

üìÑDescription
In this live session, you will learn about the capabilities of SAP Customer Data Platform Groups and Relationships, and how they apply to cover B2B scenarios for Accounts (customer companies) and B2B Activity Data. The session will also include an end-to-end demo with a straightforward common B2B scenario covering Order Activity for Regions, Accounts, and B2B Customers.

Topics will include:

  • Getting to know SAP CDP: Introduction and Capabilities
  • Explaining Groups and Relationships
  • An end-to-end B2B CDP use case: Order Activity per Regions, Accounts, and B2B Customers
  • General discussion on B2B scenarios and use-cases with the audience: questions and answers

üîóMore Info

üîÆLive Session: Unlock the Future: Predicting Customer Behavior with SAP Customer Data Platform AI Workbench, 

üìÖDate: 11/5/2025

üìÑDescription
What if you could predict the possible loss or engagement level of your customers? Join us and learn about creating analytic dashboards that reflect potential future customer behavior by setting up Churn and Customer Lifetime Value models around your customer data, including individual profiles (B2C) or companies (B2B). Publish different versions of your model runs into Predictive Indicators that can be used to profile your customer data into different segments and anticipate customer behavior before it happens. Unleash the future of your customer actions by using our powerful pre-trained AI models that can deeply crawl into your customer data and tell you what will happen next. Join us in this live session where we will explore every aspect of SAP Customer Data Platform AI Workbench capabilities and features!

üîóMore Info

entry.title: Re: Capturing 2 STIP EMP group on Worksheet in SAP SF VPay
entry.content: I agree with John. The standard functionality of the details and aggregation should show all the relevant STIP groups for the period and explain the calculation. The STIP groups per assignments should calculate and then aggregate on the entry level. You could use a ALCF to track the number of assignments and then a count of more than one would direct the planner to look at the details. This requirement has no impact on the accuracy of the calculation of the bonus, it is just something that makes the client feel better about the data. My approach would be to consult with the client and determine how critical this requirement is to the program, does it really add value and if it is worth all the configuration/changes you would have to make.

I checked some other plants like 1000.. and the opening and closing balances are same. Even the total receipt and issue are different (which is fine). T MB5B Valuated Stock Valuation Area: 1200 Material: LNG Description: LNG Item Quantity (TO) Stock/Value on 01.01.2025 506.836 Total/Value of Receipts 1,072.420 Total/Value of Issues -763.833 Stock/Value on 31.01.2025 815.423 Plant 1200 Kaduna Material LNG Description LNG Stock on 01.01.2025 27.596 TO Total Receipts 1,160.640 TO Total Issues 696.993- TO Stock on 31.01.2025 491.243 TO The plant I reviewed all transactions within the same period, I found that 52 document numbers in the Valuated Stock report (movement type 641, without storage location) are not reflected in the Storage Location/Batch stock.

entry.title: Re: Solution manager Charm 7.2 on premise integration wit...
entry.content:
Hi!

As far as I know, there is no real SAP offering for this. The SAP AddOn Focused Build (FB) has some integration capabilities (please see here), but only the creation of a Requirement is offered. All other integrations have as a prerequisite, that the ChaRM/FB Change Document has already been created in FB and offer only some synchronization like status change or text addition.

There is the SAP note https://me.sap.com/notes/2556872/E , but you told that you are not interested into ITSM.

Therefore there are many offerings from SAP partners which close the gap, for example by crossALM or Galileo Group, or - tada! - by me üòé. I wrote for my main customer blue.works an API that allows external systems like Jira or Service Now to create and manage ChaRM and Focused Build documents, covering Project, Wave, Release, Configuration Item and so on.

entry.title: Re: SAP MII workbench for SAP ME 15.5 upgrade is not open...
entry.content:
Hi @Sah1 ,

are you opening it directly from XMII>Content Development>Workbench? Or maybe did you downloaded it to trigger it with a batch?

If you open directly from Workbench using the Oracle JDK 8 with javaws.exe you need to change the extension from *.jsp to *.jnlp

If you are using the download option (XMII>Content Development>Tools and Archives>Workbench Launcher) you need to download the workbench every time you update the XMII components. 

We have faced this issue every time we updated the XMII components, and also when we migrated from version 15.1 to version 15.4. We found the solution here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3052506/E I hope it may help.

 

KR Maria

entry.title: How to access the SAP HANA Cloud database behind a BTP ABAP Environment instance?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

we are currently working with the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and would like to better understand the technical access to the SAP HANA Cloud instance that runs behind it. We are aware that the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance is managed by the SAP ABAP Environment, but we are unsure about the supported ways to access it or extend it with custom database artifacts.

We have two related questions:

1. Direct access to the database
Is it possible to connect directly to the SAP HANA Cloud instance behind the BTP ABAP Environment ‚Äî for example via Database Explorer or any external SQL tool ‚Äî in order to create or inspect custom SQL views or procedures?
We already tried to create a SAP HANA Cloud project in SAP Business Application Studio, but the setup failed with the message that no database instance is available, even though we know the ABAP Environment uses a managed HANA Cloud instance in the background.
If such access is possible, where can we find or retrieve the database credentials / connection details?

2. Access pattern for SaaS scenarios
We are planning to build SaaS solutions on top of the BTP ABAP Environment.
In our CAP-based SaaS applications, we can retrieve tenant-specific database (hdi container) credentials via the Service Manager.
Is there a similar mechanism available in the BTP ABAP Environment to programmatically access or manage database connections (hdi containers) for different tenants?

If direct access is currently not possible, is it planned or on the SAP roadmap to allow connecting to the managed HANA Cloud instance in the future?

Any guidance, documentation, or personal experience around this would be very much appreciated!

Maybe @FrankJentsch can also share some insights here, since you have been very active around BTP ABAP Environment topics in the past.

Thanks & kind regards
Johannes

entry.title: Re: Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect and Enrolling with Existing Databricks
entry.content:
Hi @daniel_schubert_bixconsulting,

Thanks for your question. This topic might be a bit blurry now. I'll try to give an overview.

The capacity units (CUs) in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) are a flexible metric used to measure consumption across various services within the BDC ecosystem. They are designed to allow customers to scale services up or down as needed within a specific month. The CUs are fungible, meaning they can be used across all BDC services, which include SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks, among others. This flexibility is particularly beneficial for customers transitioning workloads, such as those moving from BW to Datasphere or SAP Databricks.

As you well said, currently, there is no specific mention of a CU Estimator for BDC Connect. However, the general principle is that CUs are allocated based on the consumption needs of the specific services being utilized. For example, in SAP Analytics Cloud, the consumption of CUs is based on the number of users provisioned for each service, such as BI, Planning Standard, and Planning Professional.

The allocation and calculation of CUs depend on the system type and the specific configurations set by the customer. For SAP-managed systems, the entire quantity of capacity units defined in the contract is automatically assigned. In contrast, for customer-managed systems, the allocation is based on the configuration set within SAP Datasphere's system.

I hope that sheds some light to your question. If you'd like to discuss this further, I'm here to help, and learn together!

I encourage you to visit the following pages:

Public Consumption Card

SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator

BR,

Eduardo

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Storing Rejection Reasons for Activi...
entry.content:
Hello Aziz, Reasons of rejection in Crowd Workforce (SAP Field Service Management) are typically stored within the activity logs or backend database, but their visibility depends on system configuration and role permissions. In SAP Field Service Management‚Äôs Crowd Workforce module, when an activity is rejected, the system prompts for a rejection reason. However, where this reason is stored and how it's accessed can vary depending on your setup

You will find the rejection reasons in below areas as explain.

Activity History Logs: Rejection reasons are often recorded in the activity‚Äôs audit trail or history log. This allows managers and admins to trace decisions made during the assignment lifecycle.

Backend Database: The reason may be stored in a specific field tied to the activity object in the database. Accessing this typically requires backend or API-level permissions.

Partner Portal or Technician View: Depending on your configuration, crowd partners or technicians may see rejection reasons in their assignment dashboard or notification panel.

Reporting Tools: If your organization uses reporting or analytics tools integrated with SAP FSM, rejection reasons can be extracted and analyzed from those datasets.

Hope the above explanation helps you.

entry.title: Export Balance Before and Balace After values

entry.title: Triggering next production operation in MES after subcontracting receipt with quality inspection
entry.content:
Hello everyone,
I‚Äôm currently working on an S/4HANA Manufacturing project, where we have a complex subcontracting flow that integrates PP, QM, EWM, and MES.

Here‚Äôs the process we have defined so far:

  1. A production order (PO) includes two subcontracting operations:

    • Operation 30 (service) ‚Üí Represents the subcontracted activity itself (the external service).
      ‚Üí This operation generates an automatic purchase requisition.

    • Operation 35 (Log) ‚Üí Represents the logistical flow for sending and receiving the parts to/from the subcontractor.
      ‚Üí This operation also generates an automatic purchase requisition (Log) for the physical goods movement.

  2. Once the subcontracted part is received, it goes into Quality Inspection (Q-stock).

  3. After the Usage Decision (UD) (321 movement from Q ‚Üí unrestricted), the part becomes available again and must be consumed in the next internal operation (e.g., operation 40).

The main challenge:

After the subcontracted part is received (and still under QM inspection), the two subcontracting operations (30/35) are automatically set to status ‚ÄúExternal Activity Delivered.‚Äù

However, the MES and operators on the shop floor must know when the part is released from QM (after UD) so that they can:

  • Start the next internal production operation (40) in the MES,

  • Trigger the material staging (servi) for operation 40 only when the part is truly available (unrestricted use).

We‚Äôre looking for a standard or best practice to automatically trigger the start or readiness of the next operation in MES (or staging in EWM) after the QM Usage Decision.

What we‚Äôve considered:

  • Triggering via the operation confirmation of Presta/Log (not reliable).

  • Triggering via PO confirmation from the subcontractor (too early).

  • Triggering via the Usage Decision (321) ‚Äî seems the most logical event.
    ‚Üí But we‚Äôre unsure how to best synchronize this with the MES interface (MAN_107_I_023 or equivalent).
    ‚Üí We also considered linking the 321 event to an automatic stock posting in EWM to stage the part for the next operation.

What we are looking for:

Has anyone already implemented this type of Manufacturing + QM + MES integration for subcontracted parts?
How did you handle the event-based trigger between the Usage Decision and the MES availability signal?
Any standard S/4HANA feature that could cover this ?

Any reference, blog, or customer experience would be greatly appreciated

entry.title: Re: Image / Picture Upload in Material master and visible...

entry.title: Re: Error of ME807
entry.content:
Hello Rathod,

Your PO is saving but not displaying due to a number range issue in the Purchase Info Record (ME11), causing the ‚ÄúExpress Document Update was cancelled‚Äù error. Fixing the number range and disabling Info Update can resolve it.

Please find below the steps to resolve the issue.

What i analyize with your issue the root cause is, the error ‚ÄúExpress Document Update was cancelled‚Äù typically occurs when you have below mentioned problems.

1. The number range for Purchase Info Record (PIR) is exhausted.
2. The system tries to update PIR during PO creation (ME21N), but fails due to missing or full number range.
3. Even though the PO number is generated, it doesn‚Äôt appear in reports like ME2M.

To fix the issue please follow the steps i mentioned below.

1. Check Number Range for PIR Document Types (IL & IN)
Go to transaction SNRO or SNUM:
Object: EINA (for Info Record)
Check if the number range assigned to document types IL and IN is exhausted.
If yes, create a new number range and assign it to these document types.

2. Disable Info Update During PO Creation
In ME21N, uncheck the box labeled ‚ÄúInfo Update‚Äù:
This prevents the system from trying to update the PIR.
You can still save the PO without triggering the error.


3. Verify in SM13
Check transaction SM13 for update termination logs:
Client = * (your client)
User = * (your user ID)
Status = ALL
Look for the failed update and confirm it‚Äôs related to PIR.

4. Test PO Creation Again
Try creating the PO again with ‚ÄúInfo Update‚Äù unchecked.
If successful, the PO should now appear in ME2M or ME23N.

Hope this have resolve your issue.

entry.title: Re: How to handle ‚Äúusernames‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal User IDs‚Äù and ‚Äúexternal IDs‚Äù in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hi,

I once looked into whether the Global User ID should be configured as a subject name identifier (SNI), as there are different opinions on that. From what I found, it was previously recommended to set the Global User ID as the SNI because it wasn‚Äôt yet supported as a claim in the token. At the time, this was the only way to later use it as a correlation attribute‚Äîfor example, in SAP Task Center scenarios. With current support for Global User ID in the token, this setup is no longer necessary.

Would be happy to hear any expert thoughts on this.

Best regards,

Ivelina

entry.title: Re: Has Devtoberfest just proved that ABAP is in fact dead?
entry.content:
Hi Thomas,

the sessions are around new stuff and this is definitely the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model also called RAP.

Here the data modelling is based on CDS views and hence CDS views are an important topic for ABAP developers that want to be up to date.  

All new developments in SAP S/4HANA are nowadays based on RAP and hence it is crucial for you as a developer that you know about RAP because even if you want to extend a RAP business object that has been delivered by SAP you have to know the RAP basics.  

And this is true for SAP S/4HANA public cloud as well as for SAP S/4HANA private cloud and the on premise version.   

ABAP Cloud does not mean that the ABAP code runs in the cloud. It is the programming model that allows you to write code that is cloud ready (and thus stable by definition) and which should also be used for new developments in on premise systems.

So if you want to be relevant as an ABAP developer I strongly suggest to have a look at this topics.  

Kind regards,

Andre

entry.title: More Efficiency in HR: Implementing the OpenText Employee File for SAP SuccessFactors the Right Way
entry.content:
Digital employee files have become one of the key pillars of modern HR transformation. They simplify administrative processes, ensure compliance, and relieve both HR teams and employees.

However, for many organizations, the standard capabilities of SAP SuccessFactors are not sufficient when it comes to powerful document management and automated document creation.

That‚Äôs where OpenText, the global leader in Enterprise Content Management (ECM), comes in and this blog should help companies make their implementation successful.

More Than Just Document Storage ‚Äì OpenText for SAP SuccessFactors

With the Solution Extension ‚Äú#SAP SuccessFactors Document Management Core by OpenText,‚Äù companies gain access to a modern, cloud-native solution that takes document management and document generation to the next level.

The solution consists of two core components:

  • Digital Employee File powered by OpenText Core Content Management
  • Document Generation Service powered by OpenText Core Communications

These services integrate seamlessly with key SuccessFactors modules such as Employee Central, Recruiting, and Onboarding, enabling end-to-end HR processes without media disruptions.

Key Success Factors for a Successful Implementation

Introducing a digital employee file is not merely an IT project ‚Äì it‚Äôs a strategic transformation toward a more efficient and future-proof HR operation.
Based on numerous customer projects, five key success factors have proven decisive:

1. Make an Early Decision on the File Structure of the HR file

During project preparation, it‚Äôs essential to decide whether a customized file structure will be developed or an existing one adopted.

Alternatively, companies can leverage best-practice structures provided by experienced implementation partners, built on the requirements and lessons learned from numerous HR projects. These usually have proven highly reliable and cost-efficient in real-world scenarios.

A change of the structures and file plan later can cause expensive change requests, so rather take the time to find the best approach.

2. A Consistent Strategy for International Rollouts

When rolling out global HR programs, consistency pays off in the long run.

The OpenText Employee File offers a Global HR file template ‚Äì a master blueprint that serves as the foundation for all employee files.

In multinational or multilingual environments, it‚Äôs crucial to decide early whether local requirements (e.g. translations, permissions, or legal fields) can be handled within the global template, or if a local variant is needed.

In practice, integrating local needs into one global template typically proves worthwhile. Fewer templates mean less maintenance, lower complexity, and significantly reduced operating costs.

3. A Thoughtful Permission Concept

A robust and well-designed permission model is one of the cornerstones of success.

Rather than maintaining individual roles in OpenText, it‚Äôs recommended to leverage SAP SuccessFactors Role-Based Permissions (RBP) for synchronization between the systems. This ensures consistent and efficient access control across the entire HR landscape.

Permissions should primarily be assigned at folder level, not at document level ‚Äì this approach minimizes administrative overhead.
Document-level permissions can still be applied in special cases but should remain the exception.

4. Document Generation as an Efficiency Booster
Many companies underestimate the benefits of integrated document generation ‚Äì yet it‚Äôs one of the strongest drivers of efficiency.

Automating the creation of standard documents such as employment contracts, certificates, or official letters saves time, reduces errors, and ensures consistent communication.
With all relevant employee data seamlessly pulled directly from SuccessFactors, the days of copying and pasting names, salaries, or job titles will finally be gone.

For HR teams, that translates to: less manual effort, higher quality, and greater employee satisfaction.

5. Leverage the Full Product Functionality
Beyond its core capabilities, the OpenText solution offers several powerful features that are often overlooked:

  • External document sharing (e.g., with former employees or auditors)
  • Employee self-services for generating certificates or viewing their own records
  • Workflow automation for review and approval processes
  • Office Online integration for seamless editing in the browser

These features not only increase efficiency but also drive user adoption and overall satisfaction.

Conclusion: Structure, Standards, and Smart Features Drive Success

Implementing the OpenText Employee File for SAP SuccessFactors is a crucial step toward achieving true digital HR excellence.

By making clear early decisions about structure, authorization, and functionality, organizations lay the groundwork for a sustainable, future-proof solution.

With the right strategy, what begins as an IT initiative becomes a real business enabler ‚Äì turning the digital employee file into a cornerstone of modern, efficient, and compliant HR operations.

entry.title: Re: How to Load Non-Refunded Container Deposit Amount to...
entry.content:
Hello Abdul Rafay,
To handle partial container deposit refunds in SAP S/4HANA and load the non-refunded amount to inventory cost, the recommended approach is to use Subsequent Debit via MIRO or Freight Condition Types in the PO.

following are the best practices and configuration steps to replicate your legacy ERP logic in SAP S/4HANA:

My Recommendation for SAP S/4HANA Process Flow

1. Advance Payment Handling
Use F-48 to record the down payment to the vendor.
Use F-54 to clear the down payment during invoice posting.
Then Alternatively, post to a dedicated clearing account for container deposits.

2. Refund Processing
When the refund is received:
Use F-28 or Bank Statement processing to post the incoming payment.
Clear against the container deposit account.
If partial refund is received:
Post the actual refund amount.
Leave the remaining balance in the container deposit account for adjustment.

Loading Non-Refunded Amount to Inventory
Option A
Subsequent Debit via MIRO
Use MIRO with reference to the original PO or material document.
Post a Subsequent Debit entry:
Assign a cost element linked to the inventory valuation class.
Debit the Raw Material Stock GL.
Credit the Container Deposit account.
This increases the inventory value and updates the Moving Average Price (MAP).

Option B
Freight/Custom Condition in PO
Define a custom freight condition type (e.g., ZDEP) in PO pricing schema.
Post the actual cost via MIRO when the deduction is known.
This ensures the cost flows to inventory via GR/IR clearing.

To configure please find below details.
Account Determination: Ensure the cost element used in MIRO is mapped to the correct inventory GL via OBYC settings.

Condition Type Setup: For freight/custom charges, configure condition types in MM pricing schema and link them to inventory valuation.

For audit trail: Both methods provide traceability and comply with audit requirements.

Journal Entries

ScenarioDebitCredit
Advance RecordingContainer DepositClearing Account (Vendor)
Advance PaymentClearing Account (Vendor)Bank Account
Full RefundBank AccountContainer Deposit
Partial RefundBank AccountContainer Deposit
Non-Refund AdjustmentRaw Material Stock GLContainer Deposit

Hope this have solve the purpose. If yes please respond

entry.title: Re: SAP_Transfer Project Special Project Stock (Q) Betwee...
entry.content:
One option is use movement type 351Q (goods issue from supplying plant) and 101 Q (goods receipt in receiving plant). Best suited when you want traceability, planning, and logistics integration. You need to trigger inbound delivery or transport costs.

The other option is transfer via 301Q which transfers unrestricted-use project stock from one plant to another. It‚Äôs a one-step transfer, simpler and faster. No need for PO or delivery documents. Best suited when you want a quick internal transfer without procurement steps. No need for logistics tracking or intercompany billing.

entry.title: Re: Capture ATC Errors for CDS Views Without Released API State
entry.content:
Hi @MohanKumar5 ,

ABAP_CLOUD_READINESS ATC variant and clean core checks based ATC variant support two different ATC checks procedure: the first one checks ABAP Cloud readiness and the second one clean core readiness. You need to decide which check procedure you want to apply and don't mix the checks as on your screenshot.

Now to your case. Your not-released custom wrapper CDS view ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC is in the package with "Standard ABAP" language version. If then your ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC_CLD CDS view is located in the ABAP package with ABAP for Cloud Development language version and  using the ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC, then you should get the syntax error, because it is using the not-released CDS view. If it does not happen, then please open a ticket to SAP to process this issue. If your ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC_CLD CDS view is located in the ABAP package with "Standard ABAP" language version and is using the ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC, you will not get any ATC error with clean core ATC checks.

Kind Regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Re: passing prompt values from a story to a data insight
entry.content:
From your screenshot, it looks like you want to pass a range to a variable value. This is not currently possible with URL parameters. There is an Improvement Request to implement this, which has been accepted, and the last update is that it will come in the Q4 release. 

For now, you can only pass single values or multiple values. Depending on what you are trying to achieve exactly, and what control you have over the solution, you could adjust your BW Query to rely on separate From and To variables. You could also perhaps build an array of dates for the full range and pass these as multiple values, but it is not very scalable, and you may rapidly run into URL character length limits or related problems.

The best workaround for now, if you just want to open the query in Data Analyser (not specifically a saved insight) would be to call the openDataAnalyzer() method on a table using the live model in your Story. This will pass the range variable values to data analyser without you needing to script anything else. The drill state of the resulting insight will mimic the drill state of the table in the story, and all variable vaules as well as filter values will be passed also. It also passes the context, so if the end user saves an insight from the resulting data analyser view, they will also have the option to Save and Pin the insight to the source widget, so that they can come back to it again directly from the same story (pinned insights are user-specific, users will only see their own pinned insights).

If you wanted the insight to be in a different navigational state, then you could use a hidden table with a pre-configured navigation state, and call openDataAnalyzer() on the hidden table.

Cheers, Ivan.

entry.content:

I'm having input template once data it is saved it need to run planning sequence.

I have created a button and written the code, but its failing can anyone help on this or provide alternate code

1) Planning sequence has 4 mandatory variables.

2) As soon as the user open the input template, user fill the variables that need to save in placeholder, once it is saved sequentially it need to trigger the planning sequence

Below is the code which I'm trying

Below is the place holder holding user feeded values in below for 4 variables

Moving Unique ProfitCneter to Unique_PC array
 for (var a = 0; a < MS1.length; a++) {
 if (! Unique_MS1.includes(MS1[a])) {
 Unique_MS1.push(MS1[a]).
 }
 }

// //Moving Unique mpFlag to Unique_RF1 array

if (!Unique_VER.includes(VER[b])) {
Unique_VER.push(VER[b]).
 }
 }

// //Moving Unique Hour to Unique_RlH array

 Unique_CC.push(CC[c]).
}
 }

// //Moving Unique Fiscper to Unique_FPER1 array
 for (var d = 0; d < CCO.length; d++) {
 if (!Unique_CCO.includes(CCO[d])) {
 Unique_CCO.push(CCO[d]);
 }
 }

 

 PS_1.getBpcPlanningSequenceDataSource().setVariableValue("Z4CCINX02_MSTARTEND",{values:Unique_PC});
 PS_1.getBpcPlanningSequenceDataSource().setVariableValue("Z4CISNY02_VERSIONWVC",{values:Unique_RF1});
 PS_1.getBpcPlanningSequenceDataSource().setVariableValue("Z4NIMMN01_COSTCTR",{values:Unique_RIH});
 PS_1.getBpcPlanningSequenceDataSource().setVariableValue("Z4NIMMN01_COMPCODE",{values:Unique_FPER1});


 var publicVersion = Table_1.getPlanning().getPublicVersion("All Versions");

 if (publicVersion.isDirty())
 {
 PS_1.execute();
 publicVersion.publish();
 }

 

Please do the needful, 

Thanks, and regards!

@Sac

entry.title: BW/4HANA connection to SuccessFactors using Compoundemployee soap API instead Odata API
entry.content:
Hello Team,

W want use Compoundemployee soap API instead Odata API instead of SF Odata API to connect BW/4HANA to SuccessFactors using the DP agent.

the reason is : OdataAdapter required for SF Odata API is not supported any more to run on the DP agent and it has to run in DP server in SAP HANA Database. meantime the direct connection from SAP HANA DB to SF is not allowed and it has to be through DP agent installed in a separate machine.

the DP agent , we can use SoapAdapter and use Compoundemployee Soap API instead to extract data from SF to BW/4HANA.

Appreciate your confirmation if we can use Soap API instead of OData API please  to connect BW/4HANA to SuccessFactors through SAP Data Provisioning Agent

entry.title: Guidelines for content created with generative AI
entry.content:
Use of generative AI in the SAP Community

Generative AI tools can be useful for organizing ideas or improving posts, but they can also blur the line between genuine personal contributions and machine-written text. We need to maintain a community where content reflects real experience, authentic voices, and trusted expertise.

These guidelines are meant to ensure that AI can be used responsibly without diminishing the value or confidence in member-created content. We think the the acceptable and unacceptable guidelines below strike a balance between using the power of generative AI to maintaining an authors own knowledge, perspective and voice.

What counts as "content created by generative AI"?

‚ÄúContent generated by generative AI‚Äù refers to any content created, in whole or in part, using a system that automatically generates content in response to a prompt. Examples of systems include large language models such as ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude or open source models. While these tools are designed to produce text that sounds natural and convincing, the accuracy and quality of their output can vary widely including completely fabricated content due to hallucination.

Why a policy on generative AI?

To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology.

 

What are acceptable uses of generative AI?

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as ‚ÄúThis post was assisted by GenAI.‚Äù For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 



What are unacceptable uses of generative AI?

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to ‚Äúpolish‚Äù a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

 

What happens if I don't follow these guidelines?

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author‚Äôs stated intent.

Furthermore, if a post appears to violate the acceptable use criteria, it will likely be removed along with any points or reputation it gained. Continued abuse of generative AI tools may result in moderator warnings or, for repeated violations, account suspensions or permanent bans. 

What if I am new but I still want to contribute?

All of our top contributors started with no SAP knowledge, and many built their reputations by providing answers in the community. One approach is to look for an unanswered question in a technology you are familiar with (especially one with a high view count), do some research and see if you can come up with a solution. You will learn during this process and help other community members at the same time.

 

Much like generative AI tools that are always evolving, this policy will need to evolve and be updated as unforeseen usages of generative AI require fast moderation reactions that may or may not be reflected just in time in this document, but the moderators are empowered to enforce as needed any and all steps to protect the experience of our SAP Community members as directed by management.

entry.title: Protecting the integrity of the community content
entry.content:
Generative AI tools can be powerful aids when used thoughtfully, offering speed and inspiration, but they can also produce misleading or inaccurate results if applied without real expertise. Their value comes from being trained on years of human-created knowledge, yet that is also why our community must be careful in how they are applied.

Workflows are shifting as users adopt more efficient ways to get the information needed to complete their tasks.
But one thing remains constant: people come to our community because they trust the answers, posts, and discussions written by fellow members. To preserve that trust and ensure our content remains reliable, we need clear, shared guidelines on the responsible use of generative AI within our community. 

The slippery slope

At first glance, protecting content integrity by banning all GenAI-assisted content generation may seem a simple choice. But that would ignore the fact that GenAI can be a powerful aid in creating content (it even played a role in drafting this). The trick is developing guidelines that lets users take advantage of these tools to enhance their productivity. Consider this scenario:

About 75% of traffic in our community happens in the Q&A/Forums section, where people come looking for solutions to specific problems. The traditional workflow has looked something like this:

  • You run into a problem and start with a Google search.
  • From the results, you open a handful of promising pages, read through them, and piece together enough information to solve your issue or at least get enough of a hint.
  • If that doesn‚Äôt work, you post a question. If your post doesn‚Äôt include enough detail, there‚Äôs a back-and-forth in the comments until someone can provide a solid answer. That process may take time.

With generative AI, the workflow shifts:

  • You may still search as before.
  • More often, you open your preferred generative AI tool, start with a quick prompt, invest more time in writing a prompt if needed, and engage in a rapid back-and-forth until you get a usable answer or enough direction to move forward. In practice, the tool is drawing on nearly all available content at once.
  • If you still don‚Äôt get what you need, only then might you open a new question or discussion thread.

With this as a standard workflow now and access to many geneartive AI tools, it is tempting to take any unanswered question, paste it into a GenAI tool, copy the response and paste in the answer. The danger here is if the person posting the answer doesn‚Äôt actually know if it is correct or not.
This creates two problems if the answer is wrong:

  1. the original poster will believe it to be correct, try it, wasting their time and diminishing the perceived value of the community.
  2. if incorrect data remains in the community, it will be scraped by the generative AI models, used in their training or RAG systems, decreasing the quality of answers (until it is removed).

This community exists to share knowledge and experience between real people. AI tools cannot ensure accuracy, provide verifiable sources, or account for the nuances of real-world problem solving. Allowing AI-authored posts without the author verifying the content risks:

  • Spreading incorrect or misleading information.
  • Eroding the trust between members.
  • Diminishing the long-term value of our content.

Acceptable use of generative AI tools

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as ‚ÄúThis post was assisted by GenAI.‚Äù For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 


Unacceptable use of generative AI tools

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to ‚Äúpolish‚Äù a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author‚Äôs stated intent.

A TLDR summary (intentionally at the end) or guiding principle is:

Anything you post in the community should represent your thinking, experience, and knowledge.
AI may assist you in the creation, but it cannot substitute for your voice. 
To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology. 

The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group.

entry.title: Re: Posting of Recognized Revenue for Cost‚ÄëBased Percenta...
entry.content:
Hello @summy

Have a look at https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/7fd9ad1108b94403a2871cf348d4b891.html?locale=en-US for more details.

In summary, based on the details and screenshots you provided, the system has calculated correctly as it was designed.

The reason is, when Recognised Revenue equal 0 JPY, it means the Planned Revenue has not been maintained in the project plan data. The cost-based POC method requires both planned Cost and Planned Revenue values to calculate and post recognised revenue.

Mathematically, this means POC equals 50% but then 50% multiplied by 0 Planned Revenue equals 0.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to configure a number range of material number in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
entry.content:
What is the way to configure a range of material number on a tenant of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to configure a number range of material number in...
entry.content:
Hello team,

To configure the internal and external number ranges for products/materials, you can use the Configuration Activity/SSCUI 102282 "Define Number Ranges for Each Material Type".
This configuration activity is located in the following IMG path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Basic Settings > Material Types > Define Number Ranges for Each Material Type.

If you encounter any issues while attempting to update the number ranges, I recommend reading this helpful blog post:

  • How does number ranges work in Product Master SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud? | SAP Community.

It provides detailed explanations of common errors and their resolutions.

Kind Regards,
√çcaro
SAP Support
